No. 81. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, October 9, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit, herewith, copies of Consular correspondence, (Other than that relating to the estates of A. M. Miller and William Parker) between the Liberian Government, its specially appointed Commission, the American Consul, Hon James Boyle,-- Liverpool and this Consulate General.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, C. General Enclosure, A letter to Auditor War Department.
Copy
No. 29/1901. Miscellaneous Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia. September 2, 1901.
Hon. W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State, Monrovia.

Sir: I have the honor to say that by reqeust of the American Consul at Liverpool, I have to ask that you be so kind as to secure (at the earliest possible moment) from the clerk of the Monthly and Probate Count of Grand Bassa County, an exact and duly certified copy of the last will and Testament of the late James H. Logan, deceased. I desire that the clerk accounts by and specially certify with his official seal attached to his signature that he is the clerk of said Court and that the instrument of writing sent is a true copy of the original will
will and Testament of the late James H. Logan, deceased.

In addition to the foregoing, I would be pleased to have both the judge of the monthly and probate court, and the Superintendant of said County, to attach their official signatures and seals of office to their respective signatures, certifying explicitly, that the said instrument of writing is an exact and faithful copy of the original Will and Testament of James H. Logan, deceased, on file in said office.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General
Copy.
No. 30/1901 Miscellaneous. Consulate General of the United States. Monrovia, Liberia, September 2, 1901.
Hon. James Boyle, United States Consul, Liverpool.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt August 30, 1901, of your note of August 9, 1901, relative to securing for you as evidence as per British law, in your prosecutiion of the claim of Mrs. Amelia A. Chase of Provincetown Massachusetts for £127, in the hands of Mess'rs Nicholas Waterhouse and Sons of Liverpool, against the estate of the late James H. Logan, deceased of Grand Bassa County, Liberia; a certified copy of the last Will and Testament of
of the said James H. Logan.

In reply to your Note, I have to say that I called upon the President of Liberia, the following day, August 31, 1901, relative to said matter. After stating to him the circumstances of the case coupled with the fact that I advised M. C. Atwood Esq., of Providencetown Massachusetts, the administrator of the estate of the late Captain Chase to refer the matter to you for collection from Messrs. Waterhouse and Sons; telling the President that according to British practice it was necessary that I secure a certified copy of the Will, in order that the same may be recorded in England, before you can proceed to force a collection, he assured me that he would advise that the matter of securing a certified copy of the Will be attended to through the State Department, Monrovia, and the Superintendent of Grand Bassa County Liberia.

I have this day according to his request, filed my formal written application for same with the State Department, Monrovia; and have the assurance of the Secretary of State, that the matter shall have his earliest possible attention. Therefore, hoping to be able to forward the desired certified copy of the Will to you at an early date.
I have the honor to be yours, &c., Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
Copy
Department of State, Monrovia, Liberia, Sept. 3, 1901.
Sir: I have the honor to acknwoledge the receipt of your dispatch of the 2nd instant, touching the matter of the last Will and Testament of James H. Logan, deceased.

In reply I have to inform you that the matter will be attended to as early as possible. As these are some fees to be paid the Clerk of the Monthly and Probate Count for copying the Will and certificate, I would like to inquire, to whom must be forwarded his bill for payment?
I would like to inform him so as to save time.
So far as the Judge and Superintendent's signature and seals are concerned, that is unnecessary. A

A certificate under seal from this Department, certifying that the person who signed his names as Clerk of the Monthly and Probate Court is the duly appointed and commissioned Clerk, is all that is necessary.
I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient servant, W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State, To Hon. O. L. W. Smith, U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General, Monrovia.
Copy re St. Louis Exposition
Department of State, Monrovia, Sept. 25, 1901.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your despatch of the 18th inst., with enclosure No. 1 Proclamation of President McKinley, No. 2, an invitation to this Government to take part in the International Exhibition of the Louisiana Purchase," to be held in the city of St. Louis, state of Missouri, by appointing delegates &c.
In reply, I have to inform you that the matter is under consideration and a reply to same will be forwarded you in due course.
I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient servant, W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State.
Hon. O. L. W. Smith U. S. Minister Resident and Consul General U. S. Legation, Monrovia.
Copy.
No. 36/1901 Miscellaneous. Consulate general of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, September 21, 1901.
Hon. James Boyle, United States Consul, Liverpool.

Sir: Referring to my No. 30/1901, Miscellaneous, of September 2, 1901, I now, in compliance with your request contained in your note of August 9, 1901, asking me to secure for you if possible a certified copy of the last Will and Testament of the Late James H. Logan, deceased of Grand Bassa County, Liberia, I now have the honor to transmit herewith, a certified certificate from the Clerk of the Monthly and Probate Court for Grand Bassa County certifying that Mr. Logan left no Will. Hence Mrs. M. L. Logan was appointed

appointed Administratrix and Jacob Logan administrator of the estate of the deceased James H. Logan. And as I have previously secured their endorsement and approval of the draft of the late James H. Logan in favor of Captain Josiah A. Chase for £127, upon Messrs. Waterhouse and Sons, of Liverpool, I do not now see but what you have really a strong case against them.
I yesterday received a letter from M. C. Atwood Esq., relative to costs &c, in this and former services rendered by me, in this case. I will write him direct.
I have the honor to be yours &c, Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General
